RHFedMTL: Resource-Aware Hierarchical Federated Multi-Task Learning

Xingfu Yi, Rongpeng Li, Chenghui Peng, Fei Wang, Jianjun Wu, and Zhifeng Zhao X. Yi and R. Li are with Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China (email: {yixingfu, lirongpeng}@zju.edu.cn).C. Peng, F. Wang, and J. Wu are with Huawei Technologies Co., Ltd. (email: {pengchenghui, wangfei76, wujianjun}@huawei.com).Z. Zhao is with Zhejiang Lab, Hangzhou, China (email: zhaozf@zhejianglab.com).Part of the paper has been accepted by IEEE PIMRC 2022 [1].
Abstract

The rapid development of artificial intelligence (AI) over massive applications including Internet-of-things on cellular network raises the concern of technical challenges such as privacy, heterogeneity and resource efficiency. Federated learning is an effective way to enable AI over massive distributed nodes with security. However, conventional works mostly focus on learning a single global model for a unique task across the network, and are generally less competent to handle multi-task learning (MTL) scenarios with stragglers at the expense of acceptable computation and communication cost. Meanwhile, it is challenging to ensure the privacy while maintain a coupled multi-task learning across multiple base stations (BSs) and terminals. In this paper, inspired by the natural cloud-BS-terminal hierarchy of cellular works, we provide a viable resource-aware hierarchical federated MTL (RHFedMTL) solution to meet the heterogeneity of tasks, by solving different tasks within the BSs and aggregating the multi-task result in the cloud without compromising the privacy. Specifically, a primal-dual method has been leveraged to effectively transform the coupled MTL into some local optimization sub-problems within BSs. Furthermore, compared with existing methods to reduce resource cost by simply changing the aggregation frequency, we dive into the intricate relationship between resource consumption and learning accuracy, and develop a resource-aware learning strategy for local terminals and BSs to meet the resource budget. Extensive simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of RHFedMTL in terms of improving the learning accuracy and boosting the convergence rate.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Multi-Task Learning, Mobile Edge Computing, Artificial intelligence (AI)

I Introduction

Benefiting from the rapid development of cellular networks, artificial intelligence (AI) over massive Internet-of-things (IoT) or smart phones becomes possible, and there is coming to a consensus that 6G will revolutionize as a network of AI [2, 3, 4, 5]. Meanwhile, network AI in 6G should simultaneously allow various sensing, mining, prediction and reasoning tasks across different industries and there emerges a common concern for storing and transmitting the rapidly expanded data through network in the near future [6]. Besides, the heterogeneous and complex nature of Industrial IoT (IIoT) systems has brought together many technical challenges such as privacy, heterogeneity and resource efficiency [7].

In that regard, federated learning (FL) promises to enable AI over distributed terminals with privacy [8] and has been extensively used in many scenarios [9, 10, 11]. In particular, federated learning learns a shared model by aggregating local updates from terminals while keeping the training data on the terminals for the sack of privacy [8]. Meanwhile, multi-task learning (MTL), which capably keeps more diversity with respect to models, can significantly improve the learning accuracy and the utilization of data [12, 13]. However, conventional FL works mostly focus on learning a single unified model for one unique task across the network, and are generally less competent to handle MTL scenarios with stragglers at the expense of acceptable computation and communication cost. For example, [14] proposes to adjust the frequency of global aggregation so as to better leverage the available resource, but it only focuses on learning a single global model and cannot adjust the learning process of local terminals. [15] proposes an energy-efficient computation and transmission resource allocation scheme over wireless communication networks while it does not support MTL and neglects the hierarchical network structure. [16] proposes a probabilistic user selection scheme to reduce the FL convergence time and the FL training loss. [17] proposes a resource allocation algorithm over wireless networks to capture the trade-off between the wall clock training time and the terminal energy consumption. Still, it focuses on a single-task scenario without considering the hierarchical structure. As for the resource utilization optimization of FL in wireless networks, [18] mainly derives an analytical model to characterize the performance of FL, while[19] proposes a private gradient aggregation scheme for wireless federated learning. [20] studies adaptive power allocation for distributed gradient descent. Though [21] provides a comprehensive study of the connection between the performance of FL algorithms and the underlying wireless network, it only talks about the energy consumption of each user into consideration and cannot adjust the energy consumption of the complete learning process. Foremost, within the scope of federated learning, although Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) has become popular for solving supervised machine learning optimization problems [8, 14], the coupling of multiple learning tasks makes it difficult to maintain the data privacy under the conventional FL framework.

In this paper, we focus on a resource-aware hierarchical federated multi-task learning (RHFedMTL) framework, so as to perform federated MTL for large-scale data with limited resource budget and without compromising the privacy. Notably, Stochastic Dual Coordinate Ascent (SDCA) gives stronger convergence results than the primal-only methods (e.g., SGD), at the same iteration cost [22], and previous works of federated MTL such as CoCoA [23, 24] use the state-of-the-art primal-dual framework with SDCA. However, it only focuses on distributed optimization method and cannot handle the unique systems challenges (e.g., stragglers) of the federated environment [13]. MOCHA [13] attempts to present the federated multi-task learning and shows that MTL is a natural choice to handle statistical challenges in the federated setting. However, one task in MOCHA corresponds to one terminal, which becomes computation-intensive and even impractical, since the required computation resources grow exponentially along with the increase of the number of terminals. Meanwhile, in practice, it is quite common to allocate multiple terminals within one region (e.g., one BS) to perform one task together. Furthermore, both CoCoA and MOCHA neglect the technical challenges such as hierarchical resource management. Though [25] introduces a client-edge-cloud hierarchical federated learning algorithm with multiple edge servers performing partial model aggregation to reduce communication cost, it does not support MTL and thus is unable to cope with unique systems challenges (e.g., stragglers) of the FL environment. Besides, the resource management of previous works are static (i.e., not resource-aware) and cannot adjust the local learning process of terminals to balance the trade-off between resource cost and learning performance [26, 27, 14, 25].

Therefore, inspired by the natural cloud-BS-terminal hierarchy of cellular works, we propose a resource-aware hierarchical federated MTL (RHFedMTL) method, where each BS is responsible for training one learning task with the aid of attached terminals while the cloud takes charge of aggregating the multi-task results. Furthermore, benefiting from primal-dual optimization method, we transform the global primal optimization problem into separate dual sub-problems across BSs, so as to guarantee the privacy. Moreover, such a problem-splitting lays the very foundation for further developing a resource-aware learning strategy, as the proved relationship between the learning accuracy and the number of iterations as well as the trade-off between the terminal iteration and the BS iteration. Compared with the existing works, our main contributions in this paper are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We leverage a hierarchical structure for federated MTL on top of the primal-dual method SDCA, and propose a RHFedMTL method, which boosts the flexibility of MTL and enables the learning of different specified models over massive terminals without compromising the privacy.

  2. 2.

    We provide the derived convergence bound of the vanilla HFedMTL, and unveil the relationship between the terminal iteration number and the BS iteration number required to converge.

  3. 3.

    On top of the aforementioned derived relationship, within RHFedMTL, we propose an resource-aware algorithm RHFedMTL, which dynamically adapts the terminal iteration number and corresponding BS iteration number to balance the trade-off between learning accuracy and resource cost, so as to reach superior performance with limited resource budget.

  4. 4.

    We evaluate the performance of the RHFedMTL algorithm via extensive simulations, and validate its effectiveness, robustness and resource-awareness.

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the details of system model, present some preliminaries of federated multi-task learning, and introduce the resource-constrained problem. In Section III, we propose the vanilla HFedMTL algorithm and derive the dual problem. Section IV gives the RHFedMTL algorithm and discusses how to dynamically set the terminal iteration number based on the provided convergence analysis. Section V gives the simulation scenarios and demonstrates the numerical results. We conclude the paper in Section V.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

II-A System Model

We primarily consider a resource-intense hierarchical mobile computing environment with multiple task models to be learned. In particular, we assume there exist N𝑁N BSs (i.e., B1,⋯,BNsubscript𝐵1⋯subscript𝐵𝑁B_{1},\cdots,B_{N}) connected to the cloud server, each corresponding to one of N𝑁N coupled tasks. Meanwhile, each BS Bbsubscript𝐵𝑏B_{b}, b∈{1,⋯,N}𝑏1⋯𝑁b\in\{1,\cdots,N\} covers Nbsubscript𝑁𝑏N_{b} terminals Tb,tsubscript𝑇𝑏𝑡T_{b,t}, t∈{1,⋯,Nb}𝑡1⋯subscript𝑁𝑏t\in\{1,\cdots,N_{b}\} (e.g., smart phones, IoT devices), each collecting Sb,tsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡S_{b,t} samples of data. Targeting to learn models 𝒘bsubscript𝒘𝑏\bm{w}_{b}, b∈{1,⋯,N}𝑏1⋯𝑁b\in\{1,\cdots,N\} for all N𝑁N tasks, the MTL can be formulated as computing model parameters from local datasets

min𝐖,𝐑{\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{W},\mathbf{R}}\Bigg{\{} 1N∑b=1N(1nb∑i=1nbℒ(𝒘b⊺𝒙bi)+λ12∥𝒘b∥2+ℛb(𝒘b))}\displaystyle\frac{1}{N}\sum_{b=1}^{N}\bigg{(}\frac{1}{n_{b}}\sum_{i=1}^{n_{b}}\mathcal{L}(\bm{w}_{b}^{\intercal}\bm{x}_{b}^{i})+\frac{\lambda_{1}}{2}\|\bm{w}_{b}\|^{2}+\mathcal{R}_{b}(\bm{w}_{b})\bigg{)}\Bigg{\}}
s.t.formulae-sequence𝑠𝑡\displaystyle s.t.\quad ybi=𝒘b⊺​𝒙bi∀i∈{1,…,nb},b∈{1,…,N},formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑏⊺superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑏𝑖formulae-sequencefor-all𝑖1…subscript𝑛𝑏𝑏1…𝑁\displaystyle y_{b}^{i}=\bm{w}_{b}^{\intercal}\bm{x}_{b}^{i}\quad\forall i\in\{1,\ldots,n_{b}\},b\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, (1)

where nb≜∑t=1NbSb,t≜subscript𝑛𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑡1subscript𝑁𝑏subscript𝑆𝑏𝑡n_{b}\triangleq\sum_{t=1}^{N_{b}}S_{b,t} represents the total number of data distributed under BS b𝑏b (i.e., task b𝑏b) and the superscript ⊺⊺\intercal indicates the transpose operator. ybi≜𝒘b⊺​𝒙bi≜superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑏⊺superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑏𝑖y_{b}^{i}\triangleq\bm{w}_{b}^{\intercal}\bm{x}_{b}^{i} corresponds to the output for input of 𝒙bisuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑏𝑖\bm{x}_{b}^{i} in local dataset under BS Bbsubscript𝐵𝑏B_{b}. In summary, 𝐖≜[𝒘1​⋯​𝒘Nb]≜𝐖delimited-[]subscript𝒘1⋯subscript𝒘subscript𝑁𝑏\mathbf{W}\triangleq[\bm{w}_{1}\cdots\bm{w}_{N_{b}}] and 𝐑≜[ℛ1,…,ℛb,…,ℛN]≜𝐑subscriptℛ1…subscriptℛ𝑏…subscriptℛ𝑁\mathbf{R}\triangleq[\mathcal{R}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{R}_{b},\ldots,\mathcal{R}_{N}] represents the weights of all BSs and the MTL regulation function for all tasks, respectively. Consistent with the single-task learning, the MTL in (1) imposes an ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2}-regulation with constant λ1>0subscript𝜆10\lambda_{1}>0. Nevertheless, MTL adds regulation functions ℛb​(𝒘b)subscriptℛ𝑏subscript𝒘𝑏\mathcal{R}_{b}(\bm{w}_{b}) to reflect the relationship among tasks. Typically, assumptions on MTL regulation functions can be categorized into two groups, dependent on the a-priori existence of the relationships amongst tasks [13]. Specifically, [28, 29] assume that the coupling structure between different tasks is known a priori while [30] assumes unknown yet learnable relationships between different tasks. Taking the example of the former case, consistent with [31], we could directly adopt an ℒ2subscriptℒ2\mathcal{L}_{2} regulation on 𝑾𝑾\bm{W} to constrain the difference of models amongst different tasks while reflecting the probably resemblance between the learning tasks (to a reference task). Mathematically, such a regulation could be formulated as

ℛb​(𝒘b)=λ22​‖𝒘b−𝒓‖2,subscriptℛ𝑏subscript𝒘𝑏subscript𝜆22superscriptnormsubscript𝒘𝑏𝒓2\mathcal{R}_{b}(\bm{w}_{b})=\frac{\lambda_{2}}{2}\|\bm{w}_{b}-\bm{r}\|^{2}, (2)

where 𝒓≜1N​∑b=1N𝒘𝒃≜𝒓1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑁subscript𝒘𝒃\bm{r}\triangleq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{b=1}^{N}\bm{w_{b}} and λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} indicates the relative importance of the multi-task regulation to the overall loss in (1). Meanwhile, as for the second case, the multi-task regulation function ℛbsubscriptℛ𝑏\mathcal{R}_{b} can be set as

ℛb​(𝒘b)=1N​λ2​tr​(𝑾​𝛀−1​𝑾⊺),subscriptℛ𝑏subscript𝒘𝑏1𝑁subscript𝜆2tr𝑾superscript𝛀1superscript𝑾⊺\mathcal{R}_{b}(\bm{w}_{b})=\frac{1}{N}\lambda_{2}\text{tr}(\bm{W}\bm{\Omega}^{-1}\bm{W}^{\intercal}), (3)

where tr​(⋅)tr⋅\text{tr}(\cdot) denotes the trace of a matrix. Furthermore, the multi-task relationship matrix 𝛀𝛀\bm{\Omega} in (3) can be learned from data. In this work, we primarily focus on the former case in (2) while our work can be extended to the latter one with an additional learning loop.

II-B Problem Formulation

In resource-intense mobile computing environment, it is of vital importance to limit the amount of resources to achieve a target error of the loss function, so as to keep the operational cost low on the basis of no system backlog. Hence, the formulation in (1) shall be complemented with the resource constraints. Consistent with [14], the terminology of “resources” here is generic and can include time, energy & economic cost related to both computation and communication. Without loss of generality, assume that there exists J𝐽J types of resources and the resource cost for the same type of devices is equal. Cj,tolsubscript𝐶𝑗tolC_{j,\text{tol}} and Cj,budsubscript𝐶𝑗budC_{j,\text{bud}}, for j∈{1,…,J}𝑗1…𝐽j\in\{1,\ldots,J\}, represents the total resource consumption and the budget of type-j𝑗j resource respectively. We mainly focus on the resource consumption of terminals and BSs due to its natural importance in the mobile network. Besides, the standard resource consumption of type-j𝑗j resource for a terminal and a BS to perform an iteration step is defined as Cj,devsubscript𝐶𝑗devC_{j,\text{dev}} and Cj,BSsubscript𝐶𝑗BSC_{j,\text{BS}} respectively. Furthermore, assume that an hierarchical iteration methodology is adopted here. In other words, one server iteration includes multiple BS iterations, while one BS iteration encompasses several terminal iteration. Consequently, on the basis of M𝑀M server iterations, for K𝐾K BS iterations and Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} terminal iterations under certain BS Bbsubscript𝐵𝑏B_{b} (b∈{1,…,N}𝑏1…𝑁b\in\{1,\ldots,N\}), the type-j∈{1,…,J}𝑗1…𝐽j\in\{1,\ldots,J\} resource consumption shall be bounded as

K​M​∑b=1N(Cj,BS+Nb​Hb​Cj,dev)≤Cj,bud.𝐾𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑁subscript𝐶𝑗BSsubscript𝑁𝑏subscript𝐻𝑏subscript𝐶𝑗devsubscript𝐶𝑗bud\displaystyle KM\sum_{b=1}^{N}\big{(}C_{j,\text{BS}}+{N_{b}}H_{b}C_{j,\text{dev}}\big{)}\leq C_{j,\text{bud}}. (4)

In other words, the MTL problem in (1) can be re-formulated as (5). In the paper, for the coupled MTL, we resort to developing a resource-aware federated solution to yield a learning methodology with appropriate K𝐾K and Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b}, on the basis of fundamental federated assumptions (i.e., no-violation of the privacy concerns).

III Hierarchical Federated Multi-Task Learning

The coupled MTL models make it challenging to directly compute the parameters without knowing all the dataset distributed among terminals. In this part, inspired by the primal-dual methodology, we talk about how to formulate the dual formulation of (5) and decompose the global problem into distributed sub-problems without sacrificing the privacy of local terminals.

We define 𝜶𝜶\bm{\alpha} to be the concatenation of all the dual variables αbisuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏𝑖{\alpha}_{b}^{i}. Mathematically, 𝜶≜[𝜶1,…,𝜶b,…,𝜶N]≜𝜶subscript𝜶1…subscript𝜶𝑏…subscript𝜶𝑁\bm{\alpha}\triangleq[\bm{\alpha}_{1},\ldots,\bm{\alpha}_{b},\ldots,\bm{\alpha}_{N}], where 𝜶bsubscript𝜶𝑏\bm{\alpha}_{b} is the concatenation of all the dual variables under the same BS and can be represented in two inter-changeable forms: (i) 𝜶b≜[αb1,…,αbnb]≜subscript𝜶𝑏superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏1…superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏subscript𝑛𝑏\bm{\alpha}_{b}\triangleq[{\alpha}_{b}^{1},\ldots,{\alpha}_{b}^{n_{b}}] is a simple combination of all the dual variables distributed among various terminals under one BS, where αbisuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏𝑖{\alpha}_{b}^{i} is the dual variable for the data point (𝒙bi,ybi)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑏𝑖(\bm{x}_{b}^{i},{y}_{b}^{i}). (ii) 𝜶b≜[𝜶[1],…,𝜶[t],…,𝜶[Nb]]≜subscript𝜶𝑏subscript𝜶delimited-[]1…subscript𝜶delimited-[]𝑡…subscript𝜶delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑏\bm{\alpha}_{b}\triangleq[\bm{\alpha}_{[1]},\ldots,\bm{\alpha}_{[t]},\ldots,\bm{\alpha}_{[N_{b}]}] where 𝜶[t]∈ℝSb,tsubscript𝜶delimited-[]𝑡superscriptℝsubscript𝑆𝑏𝑡\bm{\alpha}_{[t]}\in\mathbb{R}^{S_{b,t}} is the concatenation of dual variables corresponding to the local dataset of terminal Tb,tsubscript𝑇𝑏𝑡T_{b,t}.

We leverage the following lemma to demonstrate the equivalence between the primal problem and the aggregation of decomposed sub-problems at each BS, thus facilitating the subsequent analysis of an hierarchical federated MTL solution.

Lemma 1.

where

Proof.

The proof is a direct application of the definition of the conjugate function and we leave it in Appendix. ∎

Lemma 1 implies the MTL problem can be solved according to several sub-problems by individual BSs. Next, we resort to the following methods to tackle each sub-problem. For each sub-problem of (7), coordinate ascent methods have proven to be very efficient since it requires no step size, and has a well-defined stopping criterion given by the duality gap [23]. We use stochastic dual coordinate descent (SDCA) method which has proven very suitable for use in large-scale problems, while giving stronger convergence results than the primal-only methods (e.g., SGD) at the same iteration cost [22]. Given that the formulation of (7) allows terminals to find updates Δ​αbiΔsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏𝑖\Delta\alpha_{b}^{i} to the dual variables in 𝜶bsubscript𝜶𝑏\bm{\alpha}_{b} by only accessing the data (𝒙bi,ybi)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑏𝑖(\bm{x}_{b}^{i},{y}_{b}^{i}) stored locally. In other words, the terminals under the same BS can solve the related part of the subproblem locally and independently, and the algorithm could converge at a higher speed compared to gradient decent methods. Therefore, with selected data (𝒙b,ti,yb,ti)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑏𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑏𝑡𝑖(\bm{x}_{b,t}^{i},y_{b,t}^{i}) in the training process, by Lemma 1, terminal-oriented sub-problem can be formulated as

maxΔ​αbi{−ℒ∗(−(αbi+Δαbi))+nb2​(λ1+λ2)[λ22∥𝒓b∥2−∥𝒘b+1(λ1+λ2)​nb​Δ​αbi​𝒙b,ti∥2−2λ2(𝒘b+1(λ1+λ2)​nbΔαbi𝒙b,ti)𝒓b⊺]}.subscriptΔsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏𝑖superscriptℒsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏𝑖Δsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏𝑖subscript𝑛𝑏2subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜆22superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒓𝑏2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒘𝑏1subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2subscript𝑛𝑏Δsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑏𝑡𝑖22subscript𝜆2subscript𝒘𝑏1subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2subscript𝑛𝑏Δsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑏𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑏𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒓𝑏⊺\begin{split}\max_{\Delta\alpha_{b}^{i}}\bigg{\{}&-\mathcal{L}^{*}(-({\alpha}_{b}^{i}+\Delta\alpha_{b}^{i}))+\frac{n_{b}}{{2(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2})}}\bigg{[}\lambda_{2}^{2}\left\lVert\bm{r}_{b}\right\rVert^{2}\\ &-\left\lVert\bm{w}_{b}+\frac{1}{(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2})n_{b}}\Delta\alpha_{b}^{i}\bm{x}_{b,t}^{i}\right\rVert^{2}\\ &-2\lambda_{2}\Big{(}\bm{w}_{b}+\frac{1}{(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2})n_{b}}\Delta\alpha_{b}^{i}\bm{x}_{b,t}^{i}\Big{)}\bm{r}_{b}^{\intercal}\bigg{]}\bigg{\}}.\end{split} (8)

Finally, the MTL problem in (6) has been split into several sub-problems across distributed BSs, each of which can be tackled by terminals locally. Correspondingly, a hierarchical federated MTL (HFedMTL) solution, which involves a hierarchical iteration mechanism including the server iteration, the BS iteration and the terminal iteration, can be attained.

  • •

    As for each terminal iteration of the training process, terminals conduct their local training process to maximize the local optimizing function (8) and communicate with their BS periodically.

  • •

    During each BS iteration, the BSs update and distribute the model parameters after aggregating the uploaded intermediate variables of all terminals. Subsequently, the BSs upload their model to the server at a lower frequency.

  • •

    Based on the received models, the server updates the parameters of regulation function ℛbsubscriptℛ𝑏\mathcal{R}_{b} and sends the updated parameters back to terminals through their connected BSs. During the server iteration, the server generates and sends the regulation parameters to all terminals (via BSs) using the uploaded model parameters of all tasks.

In a summary, for each server iteration, the BSs will perform K𝐾K BS iterations; while for each iteration of BS Bbsubscript𝐵𝑏B_{b}, b∈{1,…,N}𝑏1…𝑁b\in\{1,\ldots,N\}, the terminals will perform Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} terminal iterations.

IV Resource-Aware HFedMTL Method

IV-A Convergence Analysis of HFedMTL

Before delving into the details of resource-aware HFedMTL, we first present the convergence analysis of HFedMTL, which will guide the designs of a resource aware solution.

Beforehand, we give a definition of the duality gap after one terminal iteration.

Definition 1.

Within each BS iteration, we define the duality gap of sub-problems specifying how far we are from the optimum on terminal t𝑡t with all other terminals fixed. Mathematically, given 𝜶[1]​…​𝜶[Nb]subscript𝜶delimited-[]1…subscript𝜶delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑏\bm{\alpha}_{[1]}\ldots\bm{\alpha}_{[N_{b}]} from Nbsubscript𝑁𝑏N_{b} terminals,

ℰDb,t​(𝜶b)≜max𝜶^[t]⁡Db​(𝜶[1],…,𝜶^[t],…,𝜶[Nb])−Db​(𝜶[1],…,𝜶[t],…,𝜶[Nb])≜subscriptℰsubscript𝐷𝑏𝑡subscript𝜶𝑏subscriptsubscript^𝜶delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝐷𝑏subscript𝜶delimited-[]1…subscript^𝜶delimited-[]𝑡…subscript𝜶delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑏subscript𝐷𝑏subscript𝜶delimited-[]1…subscript𝜶delimited-[]𝑡…subscript𝜶delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑏\begin{split}\mathcal{E}_{{D}_{b,t}}{{(\bm{\alpha}_{b})}}\triangleq\max_{\hat{\bm{\alpha}}_{[t]}}{D}_{b}(\bm{\alpha}_{[1]},\ldots,\hat{\bm{\alpha}}_{[t]},\ldots,\bm{\alpha}_{[N_{b}]})-&\\ {D}_{b}(\bm{\alpha}_{[1]},\ldots,{\bm{\alpha}}_{[t]},\ldots,\bm{\alpha}_{[N_{b}]})&\end{split} (9)

We also have the following assumption of the updated duality gap.

Assumption 1.

We assume that there exists Θb∈(0,1]subscriptΘ𝑏01\Theta_{b}\in(0,1] such that for any given 𝜶bsubscript𝜶𝑏\bm{\alpha}_{b}, the subproblem running on terminal t𝑡t alone returns a (possibly random) update Δ​𝜶[t]Δsubscript𝜶delimited-[]𝑡\Delta\bm{\alpha}_{[t]} after Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} terminal iterations such that the expectation of updated duality gap is bounded as:

𝐄​[ℰDb,t​(𝜶[1],…,𝜶[t]+Δ​𝜶[t],…,𝜶[Nb])]≤Θb⋅ℰDb,t​(𝜶b)𝐄delimited-[]subscriptℰsubscript𝐷𝑏𝑡subscript𝜶delimited-[]1…subscript𝜶delimited-[]𝑡Δsubscript𝜶delimited-[]𝑡…subscript𝜶delimited-[]subscript𝑁𝑏⋅subscriptΘ𝑏subscriptℰsubscript𝐷𝑏𝑡subscript𝜶𝑏\mathbf{E}\Big{[}\mathcal{E}_{{D}_{b,t}}(\bm{\alpha}_{[1]},\ldots,{\bm{\alpha}}_{[t]}+\Delta\bm{\alpha}_{[t]},\ldots,\bm{\alpha}_{[N_{b}]})\Big{]}\leq\Theta_{b}\cdot\mathcal{E}_{{D}_{b,t}}(\bm{\alpha}_{b}) (10)

Assume the loss functions ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is (1/γ1𝛾1/\gamma)-smooth. Then, consistent with [23, Proposition 1],

Θb=(1−(λ1+λ2)​nb​γ1+(λ1+λ2)​nb​γ​1n~b)HbsubscriptΘ𝑏superscript1subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2subscript𝑛𝑏𝛾1subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2subscript𝑛𝑏𝛾1subscript~𝑛𝑏subscript𝐻𝑏\Theta_{b}=\left(1-\frac{(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2})n_{b}\gamma}{1+(\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2})n_{b}\gamma}\frac{1}{\tilde{n}_{b}}\right)^{H_{b}} (11)

where n~b≜maxt⁡nb,t≜subscript~𝑛𝑏subscript𝑡subscript𝑛𝑏𝑡\tilde{n}_{b}\triangleq\max_{t}{n_{b,t}} is the size of the largest local dataset among terminals. Specifically, Θb≜1≜subscriptΘ𝑏1\Theta_{b}\triangleq 1 means that the terminals under task b𝑏b made no updates and therefore no resource consumption, while Θb→0→subscriptΘ𝑏0\Theta_{b}\rightarrow 0 implies that the duality gap comes to zero, which is unrealistic as the number of terminal iterations (and correspondingly the resource consumption) grows to infinity in this case. Therefore, ΘbsubscriptΘ𝑏\Theta_{b} indicates the resource required by the system. We also define Θ≜maxb⁡Θb≜Θsubscript𝑏subscriptΘ𝑏\Theta\triangleq\max_{b}{\Theta_{b}} to facilitate subsequent operations.

∎

Remark: Theorem 1 shows that the value of β𝛽\beta is mostly affected by the hardest task and the learning problem will always converge after an update of ℛbsubscriptℛ𝑏\mathcal{R}_{b} if we set the number for BS iterations K𝐾K sufficiently large. Hence, HFedMTL is robust to the change of multi-task learning parameters and guaranteed to converge.

Together with (11), Theorem 1 implies the following corollary.

Corollary 1.1.

The minimal K𝐾K increases given a decrease of terminal iteration number Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b}, so there exists a trade-off between the terminal iteration number Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} and BS iteration number K𝐾K.

IV-B The Description of RHFedMTL

To meet all the requirements of the resource-aware problem defined in (5), we extend the vanilla HFedMTL method to a resource-aware one so as to optimize the system model at a minimum resource cost.

Different form HFedMTL pre-defining all parameters, the resource-aware HFedMTL method is capable to be aware of the costs and budget of the system resources, so as to dynamically adjust the terminal iteration number Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} under BS Bbsubscript𝐵𝑏B_{b}, b∈{1,…,N}𝑏1…𝑁b\in\{1,\ldots,N\} and BS iteration number K𝐾K while meeting the convergence target of duality gap in (13). Recalling Theorem 1 that a larger terminal iteration number Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} increases the resource consumption linearly, but decreases the incurred duality gap non-linearly, given the resource budget, there must exists a range of feasible Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b}, within which choosing a bigger Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} will increase the terminal iteration cost, but the decreased BS iteration number K𝐾K required for convergence will decrease the overall resource consumption. The following theorem verifies the aforementioned intuitions.

Theorem 2.

Assume that the loss function ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is (1/γ1𝛾1/\gamma)-smooth, for any convergence target ϵDsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐷\epsilon_{D}, in order to solve the MTL problem in (5), if there exists a terminal iteration number Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b}, b∈{1,⋯,N}𝑏1⋯𝑁b\in\{1,\cdots,N\} satisfying (25), the problem is feasible.

Proof.

Considering the constraint in (5), a direct analysis leads to that the iteration number K𝐾K under BS Bbsubscript𝐵𝑏B_{b} should satisfy:

K≤⌊minj∈{1,…,J}⁡Cj,bud​[M​∑b=1N(Cj,BS+Nb​Hb​Cj,dev)]−1⌋.𝐾subscript𝑗1…𝐽subscript𝐶𝑗budsuperscriptdelimited-[]𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑁subscript𝐶𝑗BSsubscript𝑁𝑏subscript𝐻𝑏subscript𝐶𝑗dev1K\leq\left\lfloor\min_{j\in\{1,\ldots,J\}}C_{j,\text{bud}}\bigg{[}M\sum_{b=1}^{N}\big{(}C_{j,\text{BS}}+{N_{b}}H_{b}C_{j,\text{dev}}\big{)}\bigg{]}^{-1}\right\rfloor. (26)

Taking account the convergence analysis in Theorem 1,

K>(1−(1−Θ)​η∗T∗)​log⁡∑b=1NnbN​ϵD.𝐾11Θsuperscript𝜂superscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑁subscript𝑛𝑏𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐷K>\Big{(}1-(1-\Theta)\frac{\eta^{*}}{T^{*}}\Big{)}\log{\frac{\sum_{b=1}^{N}n_{b}}{N\epsilon_{D}}}. (27)

Rearranging (26) and (27), we can derive that:

(1−(1−Θ)​η∗T∗)​log⁡∑b=1NnbN​ϵD<⌊minj∈{1,…,J}⁡Cj,bud​[M​∑b=1N(Cj,BS+Nb​Hb​Cj,dev)]−1⌋.11Θsuperscript𝜂superscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑁subscript𝑛𝑏𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐷subscript𝑗1…𝐽subscript𝐶𝑗budsuperscriptdelimited-[]𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝑁subscript𝐶𝑗BSsubscript𝑁𝑏subscript𝐻𝑏subscript𝐶𝑗dev1\begin{split}&\Big{(}1-(1-\Theta)\frac{\eta^{*}}{T^{*}}\Big{)}\log{\frac{\sum_{b=1}^{N}n_{b}}{N\epsilon_{D}}}<\\ &\left\lfloor\min_{j\in\{1,\ldots,J\}}C_{j,\text{bud}}\bigg{[}M\sum_{b=1}^{N}\big{(}C_{j,\text{BS}}+{N_{b}}H_{b}C_{j,\text{dev}}\big{)}\bigg{]}^{-1}\right\rfloor.\end{split} (28)

Substituting (11) into (28), we have the theorem. ∎

Remark: Theorem 2 provides a feasible range of Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b}, which will help determine an appropriate terminal iteration number. On the basis of that, the chosen BS iteration number will potentially reduce the overall resource consumption.

As given in Theorem 2, the left side of (25) represents the needed resource cost to meet the convergence target ϵDsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝐷\epsilon_{D} (13) under certain number of terminal iterations. In case where N=5𝑁5N=5, Nb=5subscript𝑁𝑏5N_{b}=5, ϵD=0.01subscriptitalic-ϵ𝐷0.01\epsilon_{D}=0.01, we demonstrate in Fig. 2 the numerical relationship between the BS iteration number and the resource cost with respect to a unanimous terminal iteration number Hb=Hsubscript𝐻𝑏𝐻H_{b}=H, b∈{1,…,N}𝑏1…𝑁b\in\{1,\ldots,N\}. Accordingly, with limited resource budget Cj,budsubscript𝐶𝑗budC_{j,\text{bud}}, there exists three possible cases and they are represented by horizontal lines of different colors in Fig. 2 where the solid lines means Cj,bud>Cj,costsubscript𝐶𝑗budsubscript𝐶𝑗costC_{j,\text{bud}}>C_{j,\text{cost}} while dashed lines means Cj,bud<Cj,costsubscript𝐶𝑗budsubscript𝐶𝑗costC_{j,\text{bud}}<C_{j,\text{cost}}. Besides, the dot indicates the value of chosen H𝐻H.

  1. 1.

    The given resource budget Cj,budsubscript𝐶𝑗budC_{j,\text{bud}} is too limited to converge, just as shown as the red line in Fig. 2. In this case, RHFedMTL capably traverses all the range of Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} to minimize the resource cost of terminals (i.e., to be most resource efficient) and reduce the number of BS iterations to meet the limited resource budget.

  2. 2.

    The given resource budget Cj,budsubscript𝐶𝑗budC_{j,\text{bud}} is just enough to converge, just as shown as the blue line in Fig. 2. In this case, RHFedMTL capably traverses all the feasible range of Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} to satisfy (25), making a balance between learning speed and efficiency. Correspondingly, it sets the BS iteration number according to (12).

  3. 3.

    The given resource budget Cj,budsubscript𝐶𝑗budC_{j,\text{bud}} leads to a resource surplus, just as shown as the green line in Fig. 2. In this case, RHFedMTL can choose a appropriately smaller valid number of Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b}, so as to fully leverage the resource budget. Notably, the adaption of Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} also implies the ability to cope with the straggler issue.

Finally, under the RHFedMTL framework in Algorithm 1, we present the LocalDualMethod in Procedure IV-B.

V Simulation and Numerical Results

In this part, we illustrate the performance of the proposed RHFedMTL algorithm. Consistent with Mocha [13], we adopt a dataset consisting of mobile phone accelerometer and gyroscope data collected from 30 individuals for human activity recognition [32]. Furthermore, we attempt to classify the sitting gesture and the other activities from the provided feature vectors (i.e., time and frequency domain variables), and consider the data from different individuals as different tasks. Specifically each task contains 707070 pieces of data. In other words, there exist at most 303030 tasks, and more tasks could bring enhanced regulation as in (2) and (3). Meanwhile, the training dataset of one task is distributed among terminals while the test dataset is stored in BS for performance evaluation.

In order to express the overall performance of the system more intuitively, we calculate the overall accuracy by averaging the accuracy of all separate tasks on their test dataset under various settings, and then dive into the real-time task performance of all separate tasks lately in Fig. 7. For ease of representation and interpretation of results, we primarily consider J=1𝐽1J=1 type of resources and consider the energy as the single resource type in our experiments. The resource cost includes computational cost for terminal iteration (i.e., local training process) and BS iteration (i.e., aggregation and transmission), consistent with (5). We compare RHFedMTL with vanilla HFedMTL and classical methods including FedAVG [8]. Since RHFedMTL can adjust its terminal iteration number while others can not, we default the terminal iteration number H𝐻H for HFedMTL and FedAVG to be 2. The system parameters are summarized in Table II.

We first experiment with the relationship between terminal iteration number Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} and BS iteration number K𝐾K needed to reach target duality gap in (13). For simplicity of representation, we set H≜minb⁡Hb≜𝐻subscript𝑏subscript𝐻𝑏H\triangleq\min_{b}{H_{b}} as shown in (25) and set Hbsubscript𝐻𝑏H_{b} to be the same as H𝐻H for all BSs. The experiment results are shown in Fig. 2. Consistent with our discussions above (e.g., (11) and (25)), the terminal iteration number H𝐻H and BS iteration number K𝐾K are negatively correlated while the relationship between H𝐻H and system resource cost is not always monotonic. Therefore, if the value of Cj,BSsubscript𝐶𝑗BSC_{j,\text{BS}} is relatively large, the reduction of K𝐾K can compensate the resource cost due to the increased the terminal iteration number H𝐻H. Numerical results of chosen H𝐻H and K𝐾K under different resource budget Cj,devsubscript𝐶𝑗devC_{j,\text{dev}} is shown in Fig. 3. Due to the lack of the capability for resource awareness, HFedMTL adopts a fixed terminal iteration number and can only increase the BS iteration number to drain up the resource budget. But, as further verified in Fig. 4 and Table III, RHFedMTL can adjust H𝐻H and K𝐾K simultaneously to reach better performance under given resource budget. Moreover, given a limited resource budget, it can be observed from Fig. 3, RHFedMTL gives priority to increase the terminal iteration number since it costs less resources and gradually increases the BS iteration number to yield superior performance as the resource budget grows.

As for Fig. 4, since the dataset under one task is limited, the number of data stored in one terminal decreases as terminal number Nbsubscript𝑁𝑏N_{b} grows. Therefore, with a smaller local dataset size for terminals, RHFedMTL leads to a relatively smaller range of H𝐻H and produces performance similar to HFedMTL (i.e., similar H𝐻H and K𝐾K) in Fig. 3, it can be observed from Fig. 4 and Table III that the performance gap between HFedMTL and RHFedMTL decreases as Nbsubscript𝑁𝑏N_{b} grows. Similarly, under a resource-abundant case, the performance gap of RHFedMTL and HFedMTL will also decrease since resource budget is no longer the bottleneck to inhibit the learning performance.

In Fig. 5, we compare the model accuracy with different task numbers (i.e., different BS numbers). Benefiting from the multi-task regulation, the performance of RHFedMTL and HFedMTL increase along with the increase of the number of tasks. However, a over-larger task number will diminish the performance gain, given the complication to learn the relationship among multiple tasks. On the other hand, Fig. 6 examines the impact of terminal iteration cost Cj,devsubscript𝐶𝑗devC_{j,\text{dev}}. Consistent with our intuition, the excessive cost of terminal iteration Cj,devsubscript𝐶𝑗devC_{j,\text{dev}} will decrease the model accuracy. From the figures above, RHFedMTL and HFedMTL shows their robustness under various settings and RHFedMTL demonstrates their superiority.

In Fig. 7, we plot the accuracy of each task separately. In this simulation, the resource budget Cj,budsubscript𝐶𝑗budC_{j,\text{bud}} is 1,40014001,400 while the task number N𝑁N is 555. Since the resource budget is limited, RHFedMTL chooses a bigger terminal iteration number H𝐻H to make the system more cost-efficient. Therefore, the BS iteration number K𝐾K of RHFedMTL will be smaller accordingly and leads to fewer data points as shown in Fig. 7, as the task accuracy is evaluated after each BS iteration. Again, RHFedMTL and HFedMTL can always reach a higher accuracy than FedAVG and facilitate the learning of other tasks. As already discussed, compared with HFedMTL, RHFedMTL yields better performance.

Finall, we conduct more performance sensitivity analysis and testify the model accuracy of RHFedMTL with respect to different regulation parameter λ1subscript𝜆1\lambda_{1} and λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2}. As shown in Fig. 8, for the self-regulation parameter λ1subscript𝜆1\lambda_{1}, the model accuracy will decrease, since it will loss the functionality of self regulation if we set the value of λ1subscript𝜆1\lambda_{1} too trivial; while a over-large value of λ1subscript𝜆1\lambda_{1} can potentially degrade the performance as well. Similar phenomena can also be observed in results corresponding to multi-task regulation parameter λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2}. Therefore, we set the default value of λ1subscript𝜆1\lambda_{1} and λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2} to be 10−4superscript10410^{-4} and 10−6superscript10610^{-6}, respectively.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we have addressed the importance of network AI and proposed an RHFedMTL framework based on the primal-dual method towards tackling federated MTL problems with stragglers. In particular, RHFedMTL has taken the hierarchy of cellular works into consideration and encompassed a three-tier iteration mechanism including server iteration, BS iteration and terminal iteration. Moreover, the primal-dual method SDCA has been leveraged to effectively transform the coupled multi-task learning into some local optimization problems within BSs. We have analyzed the convergence bound of the proposed framework, and derived a guiding relationship between terminal iteration and BS iteration. Afterwards, we have developed a resource-aware learning strategy for local terminals and BSs to obtain more satisfactory learning performance under given resource budget. Extensive experimentation results have demonstrated the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method.
